pageContext.description:
The painting depicts a full-length portrait of Johann Friedrich in the official electoral attire, which trimmed with ermine. He is shown against a dark background and looks at the viewer. He holds the stately sword of the elector with both hands its point is cut off by the top edge of the painting.
[Görres, cda 2016]

metadata.title: Johann Friedrich I. the Magnanimous, Elector of Saxony

pageContext.provenance:
- the three paintings were brought from Wittenberg to Weimar together with, among others, portraits of Luther and Melanchthon during the imprisonment of Johann Friedrich and after the relocation of his residence in 1549.  The intention to store them in the Wartburg was not carried out [Junius 1926, 226-260, particularly p. 246].
- in the inventory of the 'Neues Lusthaus' from 1572 five saxon electors ('V sechsischer Churfürst') were listed among the 'Conterfetten' in the 'Mittleren Sahl' (also so-called green salon (Grüner Saal) on the first floor) (Sta W: Reg. Aa 1240-61, fol. 107); in 1602/03 they were in the same location ('Funff unterschiedliche taffeln, in rahmen gefasst, daran funff Churfursten zu Sachssen, Jeder in seinem Chur Rocke mitt dem Churschwedt Undt Hutt abgemahlt', see Sta W: A 551 a, fol. 224 v). In addition to the three present portraits the remaining two could only have depicted two of the three previous electors: Ernst (1441-1486), Friedrich II. (1412-1464) and Friedrich I. (1370-1428).
At the time of Joh. Seb. Bach the paintings were in the hereditary ranks of the court church (Hofkirche). Saved from the fire of 1774, they hung until 1804 in the Stadtkirche St. Peter and Paul, from there they were transferred to the ducal library [Großherzogliche Bibliothek) [Schöll 1847, 151, Fn.]; [Verzeichnis XVII b 44, 45, 46]
- 1869 entered the museum 

[Hoffmann, Cat. Weimar 1992, 85, 86]

restorationSurveys.overallAnalysis:
- the reverse of all three paintings is impregnated with tar and reinforced with a cradle
- numerous retouchings and overpaint, particularly in the foreground 
(Restoration from 1866) 

[Hoffmann, Cat. Weimar 1992, 84]
